abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Science and
            Technology Project are to: improve the capacity of
            Croatia's Research and Development (R&D) and
            innovation institutions to implement Europe 2020 strategy
            for increased investments in R&D through efficient
            absorption of European Union (EU) funds, and to develop a
            pipeline of public and private R&D projects, including
            research groups, that could qualify for financing through EU
            structural funds. Negative impacts most commonly include:
            dust and noise due to excavation, demolition and
            construction; management of demolition construction wastes
            and accidental spillage of machine oil, lubricants, etc.,
            encroachment to a private property, damage to historical or
            cultural property or unknown archaeological sites, traffic
            disturbance, surface or ground water, and soil pollution or
            erosion. Mitigation measures include: 1) the local
            construction and environment inspectorates and communities
            have been notified of upcoming activities; 2) during
            interior demolition use debris chutes above the first floor;
            3) there will be no open burning of construction/waste
            material at the site; 4) during operations the engine covers
            of generators, air compressors and other powered mechanical
            equipment should be closed, and equipment placed as far away
            from residential areas as possible; 5) the site will
            establish appropriate erosion and sediment control measures;
            6) waste collection and disposal pathways and sites will be
            identified for all major waste types expected from
            demolition and construction activities; 7) monitoring of new
            wastewater systems (before/after) will be carried out; and
            8) special facilities for segregated healthcare waste.
